natural solution: If we start by looking at the first inequality, we see it is equivalent to $3>x,$ so the only possible positive integers $x$ could be are $x=1$ or $x=2.$ Now, looking at the second equation, if $x=2$ we have $$3(2)-a>-6 \Rightarrow 12>a$$ If $x=1,$ then $$3(1)-a>-6 \Rightarrow 9>a.$$ We want $x=2$ to be the only solution.
Thus, we must choose $a=9,$ $10,$ $11.$ This is $\boxed{3}$ possible values.

a_1.formal problem:

 Thus, we must choose $a=9,$ $10,$ $11.$ This is $\boxed{3}$ possible values.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a x :: int
assumes h0 : "x = 2"
and h1 : "2 * x > 3 * x - 3"
and h2 : "3 * x - a > -6"
and h3 : "count [a \<leftarrow> [1..]. (\<forall>x \<in> {1..}. 2 * x > 3 * x - 3 \<and> 3 * x - a > -6)] = 3"
shows  "\<exists> a1 a2 a3. a1 \<noteq> a2 \<and> a1 \<noteq> a3 \<and> a2 \<noteq> a3 \<and> {a1, a2, a3} = {a. a \<in> [1..] \<and> (\<forall>x \<in> {1..}. 2 * x > 3 * x - 3 \<and> 3 * x - a > -6)}"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 For how many positive integral values of $a$ is it true that $x = 2$ is the only positive integer solution of the system of inequalities $$
\begin{cases}
2x>3x-3\\
3x-a>-6
\end{cases}
$$ The final Answer is 3
 ### Proof
 If we start by looking at the first inequality, we see it is equivalent to $3>x,$ so the only possible positive integers $x$ could be are $x=1$ or $x=2.$ Now, looking at the second equation, if $x=2$ we have $$3(2)-a>-6 \Rightarrow 12>a$$ If $x=1,$ then $$3(1)-a>-6 \Rightarrow 9>a.$$ We want $x=2$ to be the only solution.
 Thus, we must choose $a=9,$ $10,$ $11.$ This is $\boxed{3}$ possible values.
 *)

theorem
fixes a x :: int
assumes h0 : "x = 2"
and h1 : "2 * x > 3 * x - 3"
and h2 : "3 * x - a > -6"
and h3 : "count [a \<leftarrow> [1..]. (\<forall>x \<in> {1..}. 2 * x > 3 * x - 3 \<and> 3 * x - a > -6)] = 3"
shows  "\<exists> a1 a2 a3. a1 \<noteq> a2 \<and> a1 \<noteq> a3 \<and> a2 \<noteq> a3 \<and> {a1, a2, a3} = {a. a \<in> [1..] \<and> (\<forall>x \<in> {1..}. 2 * x > 3 * x - 3 \<and> 3 * x - a > -6)}"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: Find three distinct integers $a_1, a_2, a_3$ such that for each $a_i$, the inequality $2x > 3x - 3$ holds for all integers $x \in \{1, 2, 3, \dots\}$, and the inequality $3x - a_i > -6$ holds as well. There are exactly three such integers $a_i$.
